The Full Picture on Care Homes

After years of underinvestment by the previous Conservative administration, Lancashire's care homes were in a precarious position. Reform inherited a consultation process that was already in the pipeline — and rather than pushing through closures, they listened to the public and saved every home.

What Reform Inherited

Lancashire's adult social care budget of approximately £545 million per year — over 40% of the council's entire net revenue — was under immense pressure. The previous Conservative administration had left a requirement to find £50 million in adult social care savings over 2025/26 and 2026/27. The council's CQC rating stood at "Requires Improvement" (2.0 out of 4) — joint-lowest of any county council in England.

The consultation on the future of care homes was already in the pipeline before Reform took control in May 2025. Reform did not create this situation — they inherited both the underinvestment and the need to consult.

The Consultation

The "Living Better Lives in Lancashire" transformation programme had identified potential savings across the care system. A consultation was launched on the future of five residential care homes and five day centres. Reform was keen to consult the public wherever possible — a marked contrast to the previous administration's approach.

Over 1,600 responses were received — one of the largest consultation exercises in the council's history. The public spoke clearly: these care homes mattered to their communities.

Reform Listened — and Saved Them

In January 2026, following the consultation, Reform announced that all five care homes would be saved. Instead of closures, the council pledged new investment in all five residential homes.

This is what responsive local government looks like: after years of underinvestment, a new administration inherited a difficult situation, listened to the public through proper consultation, and acted on what residents told them.

£23 Million Delivered Anyway

Despite keeping all care homes open, the Living Better Lives programme still delivered £23 million in savings during 2025/26, with a target of £46.75 million over two years. The savings are coming from better commissioning, reduced reliance on expensive agency placements, and more efficient use of in-house provision — not from closing services that vulnerable residents depend on.

What the Critics Conveniently Forget

Under Labour (2013-2017), Lancashire's adult social care budget was cut directly:

  • Physical disability services: cut by 20%
  • Learning disability services: cut by 15%
  • Substance misuse services: cut by £500,000

Under the Conservatives (2017-2025), the CQC rating deteriorated to "Requires Improvement" while council tax was maxed out year after year.

Reform is the first administration in a decade to both protect frontline care services and deliver meaningful efficiency savings at the same time.
